title: What are your ten least favorite Beatles songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: I seem to recall that back in the early 1970s, WPLJ and the Village Voice ran a poll asking fans what their least favorite Beatles’ song (or, as Apple Corps would prefer us to style it, their least favorite song by The Beatles) was. There’s some overlap with the answers given so far here, and elsewhere. At the top of that list, and included almost de rigeur on many of these lists, is “Revolution 9”. I’m going to leave it off mine because it’s not a song. If you want to call it the worst Beatles’ track, you’re on firm semantic ground. But leave your lists of worst Beatles’ songs to tracks that have actual chord progressions and melodies, or at least sound like they were meant to. In no particular order … “Baby You’re a Rich Man”. If I had to pick one Beatles’ single I would be happy never to hear again, it’s this one. I know John wrote it to make fun of the “weekend hippies” of the era … unfortunately, he was more successful at that than even he probably wanted, and as a result the song is as annoying as they were—that whiny Mellotron lead and John’s deliberately evasive lyrical self-interview being two of the major reasons why. And also, from a modern perspective, I really don’t want the Beatles to be the sort of group that ended a song with “Baby you’re a rich fag Jew”, even if it was meant as a playful dig at Brian Epstein.“Do You Want to Know A Secret?” Probably the earliest Beatles’ song that makes a lot of these lists. And it’s easy to see why—you go from that overly melodramatic intro to that annoyingly singsong verse part that sounds like it was written for a fourth-grade music class to sing along to with their teacher. Really, the whole song sounds like it was written by some lesser songwriters who were told to write something that sounded like a Beatles song and maybe the Beatles themselves would actually record it.“Piggies” Even if Charles Manson hadn’t totally ruined this one (not, contra Bono, “Helter Skelter”), it is about as subtle, lyrically, as a sledgehammer, to the point that you start feeling sorry for the putative targets. Roger Waters did this lyrical idea much better for Pink Floyd ten years later.“Run for Your Life” Actually not a bad song musically. But lyrically totally reprehensible today, as it basically glorifies jealousy to the point of homicidal rage. To be fair, Lennon himself said, about ten years later, after he’d taken a more mature look at that aspect of himself in “Jealous Guy”, that he was deeply embarrassed by this song.“Only a Northern Song” George’s whine about not getting a share of publishing royalties equal to Paul and John was supposedly written in about 40 minutes and never meant to be recorded. But then … they ran short on material for Yellow Submarine, and guess what? There was this song just sitting there (Kiss fans may recall that something similar led to “Beth”). A shame, really, because George was also responsible for “It’s All Too Much”, that album’s only really memorable track.“Hello Goodbye” Not so much annoying to listen to as just uninspired-sounding. The “Do You Want to Know A Secret?” of their later career in that it sounds more as if some other, less talented group of songwriters had been tasked with writing a Beatles song to be recorded by the Beatles. Wears out its pretty thin lyrical conceit by the end of the first verse.“Her Majesty” You can see why they put this little bit of studio goofery at the very end of Abbey Road and didn’t bother to tell people it was there … it is useful only as a sort of inverse of the trick ending on the album’s first side (where, if you didn’t remember, “I Want You (She’s So Heavy)” just abruptly ends mid-bar, making you think something happened to the playback until you see that is indeed complete).“Good Day Sunshine” Vulture ranks this one the absolute worst Beatles song. It (or rather, a cover version) had been used in a U.S. TV commercial recently, sort of reminding me it existed, and frankly I wish they hadn’t. Musically it’s nothing special, and lyrically … well, they explored this idea with better music in “Sun King” and, on that same album, did it better than anyone else has with “Here Comes the Sun”.“Ob-La-Di Ob-La-Da” It’s well-known that if McCartney was less than thrilled about “Revolution 9” being on the White Album, Lennon felt the same way about this. I can stand hearing this every now and then, but I can easily understand how Lennon could have been driven nuts by hearing this all day in the studio.“You Know My Name (Look Up The Number)” What does it tell you about the Let It Be sessions, such as they were, that they consigned this one to a B-side? Especially when it was originally recorded earlier for the Plastic Ono Band. When you read that McCartney at one point considered this his favorite Beatles song, you understand why years later he had to write “Silly Love Songs” to explain himself.

Well, you can’t argue taste. People like/hate what they will. I still can’t help but laugh at the fact that almost all the responses have at least 2 of my favorite songs on them! So weird. There are 2 categories for me. One is of songs I don’t necessarilly dislike, but tend to skip most of the time. The other is of songs I just don’t like at all. The following is the latter category (I’m not including covers, otherwise the list would be longer): In no particular order… Octopus’s Garden. Shoulda been a B-side, if it needed to exist at all. Better yet, held for a Ringo solo album.Yesterday. The melody doesn’t make up for the lyrics. Would have preferred a song about scrambled eggs.I’m Happy Just to Dance With You. Annoying yawn.Honey Pie. Too goofy. Wayyyy too goofy. Bad Paul! Bad Paul! Go lay down. Good boy.Flying. Coulda been better, but I think they were all too fucked up to try harder.Wait. A throwaway from Help, which should have remained thrown away.Nowhere Man. It works in the movie, but too trite compared to the rest of Rubber Soul, except Wait.Dig it. Never should have been released. Luckely, they didn’t release the long version. Ouch.Let it Be. Over and over and over and over (and over) with terrible advice. The Sesame Street version (“Letter B”) is far superior.Why Don’t We Do it in the Road. Great demo, Paul! Whattaya say we get the boys together and rock this one out! No? OK, howabout giving it to a band that will have some fun with it? No? Would you consider keeping it off the album? I mean, you already have 2 songs without another Beatle playing, so, y’know. What? I’m fired? You’re fired! C’mon George, let’s get outa here!
